conclusion: Objects A and B move along the same straight line from the same starting position. Their velocities are plotted against time in a graph.
In a v-t graph, the area under the curve for each object gives the displacement of that object from the starting point.
The distance between the objects at any time t is the difference in their displacements, which is the difference in the areas under their respective v-t curves from time 0 to time t.
Object A has a straight line that starts at the origin and increases linearly with time, indicating constant acceleration.
Object B has a curve that starts high, dips down to a minimum, and then rises again, indicating changes in its velocity.

premise: The distance between them is the difference in their displacements.
conclusion: To find when they are farthest apart, find the time t where the difference in their displacements is maximum.
For object A: v_A = kt, where k is the slope of the line.
Object B's velocity curve seems to have a minimum at some point.

premise: The displacement of object A from time 0 to time t is the area under the straight line.
The difference in displacements is the distance between them.
Positions at any time t are given by initial position plus displacement.
conclusion: Position_A = (1/2)kt^2 and Position_B = initial position + displacement_B.

premise: The distance between them is |Position_A - Position_B|.
Relative velocity of object B with respect to A is v_B - v_A.
conclusion: The relative displacement of B with respect to A is the integral of (v_B - v_A) dt from 0 to t.

premise: The distance between them is the magnitude of the relative displacement.
conclusion: Find the maximum of relative_displacement(t) = âˆ«(v_B - v_A) dt from 0 to t.

premise: v_A = kt and v_B is the velocity from the curve.
conclusion: Plotting v_B - v_A against time, the area under this curve gives the relative displacement.
At t=0, v_A = 0 and v_B is positive.
